user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of lfs_setattr:
```c
int lfs_setattr(lfs_t *lfs, const char *path,
        uint8_t type, const void *buffer, lfs_size_t size) {
    int err = LFS_LOCK(lfs->cfg);
    if (err) {
        return err;
    }
    LFS_TRACE("lfs_setattr(%p, \"%s\", %"PRIu8", %p, %"PRIu32")",
            (void*)lfs, path, type, buffer, size);

    err = lfs_setattr_(lfs, path, type, buffer, size);

    LFS_TRACE("lfs_setattr -> %d", err);
    LFS_UNLOCK(lfs->cfg);
    return err;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function lfs_setattr:
#define LFS_LOCK(cfg) ((void)cfg,0)
...
#define LFS_UNLOCK(cfg) ((void)cfg)
...
#define LFS_TRACE(__VA_ARGS__) 
...
static int lfs_setattr_(lfs_t *lfs, const char *path,
        uint8_t type, const void *buffer, lfs_size_t size) {
    if (size > lfs->attr_max) {
        return LFS_ERR_NOSPC;
    }

    return lfs_commitattr(lfs, path, type, buffer, size);
}
...
typedef struct lfs {
    lfs_cache_t rcache;
    lfs_cache_t pcache;

    lfs_block_t root[2];
    struct lfs_mlist {
        struct lfs_mlist *next;
        uint16_t id;
        uint8_t type;
        lfs_mdir_t m;
    } *mlist;
    uint32_t seed;

    lfs_gstate_t gstate;
    lfs_gstate_t gdisk;
    lfs_gstate_t gdelta;

    struct lfs_lookahead {
        lfs_block_t start;
        lfs_block_t size;
        lfs_block_t next;
        lfs_block_t ckpoint;
        uint8_t *buffer;
    } lookahead;

    const struct lfs_config *cfg;
    lfs_size_t block_count;
    lfs_size_t name_max;
    lfs_size_t file_max;
    lfs_size_t attr_max;
    lfs_size_t inline_max;

#ifdef LFS_MIGRATE
    struct lfs1 *lfs1;
#endif
} lfs_t
...
typedef uint32_t lfs_size_t
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I found no uses of compiler-specific language extensions in the provided code. Specifically:

- No GCC/clang/MSVC extension tokens such as __attribute__, __builtin_*, __asm, __extension__, __typeof__, or statement-expressions ({ ... }) are present.
- No inline assembly or compiler-specific pragmas are used.
- The variadic macro LFS_TRACE(__VA_ARGS__) and use of __VA_ARGS__ are standard C99 features (not a compiler extension). The empty replacement for LFS_TRACE (when tracing is disabled) is also valid in C99/C11.
- The comma operator used in LFS_LOCK(cfg) ((void)cfg,0) is standard C, not an extension.
- Use of fixed-width integer types (uint8_t, uint32_t) and the inttypes macros (PRIu8, PRIu32) are standard C99/C11 functionality, not compiler-specific extensions.

Given the absence of any compiler-specific tokens or constructs, there are no fragments that warrant further investigation for Rule 1.2 (language extensions). If you target a pre-C99 compiler, note that variadic macros and inttypes/stdint features require C99; if that is a concern, specify the exact compiler/standard so I can re-evaluate against that constraint.
